Is all things considered from NPR News I'm Ari Shapiro and I know the Chang mid term elections are less than one week away and we're going to take a look at the money that has been pouring into these races
Billions of dollars have been spent on advertising and most of that money is going to democratic candidates
The center for Responsive Politics a nonprofit that tracks campaign money projects that a total of
Five point two billion dollars will be spent during this entire election cycle the group's executive director Sheila Krumholz joins us now to talk about how all that money is being spent welcome thank you glad to be here okay so fine point two billion how some compare
To previous mid term elections spending
This is way up from the two thousand fourteen mid term elections so five point to this cycle versus just three point eight billion in two thousand fourteen that's at thirty five percent jump and a record
And how is this money getting spent TV radio Internet social media like where would you see most of the money going right now
TV is still tops in the most competitive races and overall kind of pulling back we see that a almost a billion dollars has been spent already this cycle on media
Way uh uh from two thousand fourteen at this point in the cycle so a media advertising on TV for the competitive races a digital advertising across the board for all races yeah especially on Facebook
Yeah here it's through the roof this year Facebook spending a yes why is that you think
Well it was certainly successful in the two thousand sixteen uh election cycle for a lot of actors are so far I think as of today face because now to two hundred and Ninety six million dollars
And uh as in terms of FCC report it digital ad spending a it's one hundred and five million a with a almost ten million of that going to the presidential race so that that race has already taken off
And actually said the vast bulk of all the spending is by Democrats right right you know I'm curious when you see one side vastly outspending the other side is that a sign that that side has a good shot at winning or is it more of a sign of some insecurities and lack of confidence
I think both come into play on the one hand the Democrats are thrilled to see big numbers are in their columnist cycle and that is an asset they these candidates need money to get their message out
On both sides so uh that's a positive sign for the Democrats on the other hand to the degree that this money is coming from voters in other states
That is not so helpful and election day so there is a lot can backfire it can it can be viewed as outside meddling a by voters in other states that have nothing to do with the interests of the district or the state
That represents people who may be energized about a candidate but are unable to help them on election day when it really counts
So that's one way a lot of money can backfire are there other ways for instance could spending a lot of money on ads actually annoy voters because I talked to a lot of voters who hate getting bombarded by ads could that ... de Presse voter turnout
Certainly some of the advertising is designed to suppress voter turnout they are in opposition to a candidate as opposed to a supporting a candidate so those are going to be a especially tiresome for the voters
So more money does not necessarily mean more votes
Money does not necessarily mean more votes on election day the candidates who has spent the most typically wins however will see this ... this year whether a the Democratic a fundraising advantage will help
